indicators.justification:
According to the Law on access to information, every citizen is able to get information by putting in a written request to the State Agency for Environmental Protection and Forestry under the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic.

There are methodological guidelines for environmental statistics. The data is from the national statistics. The license of this organization is- Creative Commons "Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike" 4.0 Worldwide. 

Only two indicators are available as open data on emissions: "Air polluting emissions, Stationary sources" and "Installations for capture and detoxifying of harmful substances from gas emissions".

Sources: 
1) http://stat.kg/ru/opendata/category/306/

indicators.justification:
There are two laws that require state bodies to publish information on public finance: the Law on access to information  held by state bodies and local self-government bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic dated July 27, 2016 No. 152, and the Budgetary Code dated May 16, 2016 No. 59. 

There no specific guidance, but in practice the data on budget is published in a structured way: income, expenses, deficit, surplus, public debt. These data are available via a special state-owned instrument, called "Open budget": https://budget.okmot.kg/ru

Most of the data available is collected by the Ministry of Economy and Finance and the Social Fund.

Sources:
1) "Open budget" open data state owned web-portal https://budget.okmot.kg/ru

evidence.title: LAW OF THE KYRGYZ REPUBLIC On amendments to the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic "On access to information under the jurisdiction of state bodies and local self-government bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic"
BUDGETARY CODE OF THE KYRGYZ REPUBLIC
Budget Monitoring Portal

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
The government organized several workshops for state officials, round tables with business, hackathons with the IT sector and universities to discuss the need in data, criteria of collection, and also encouraged reuse of data from the state portal on open data. But all these initiatives happened only 1-2 times within the World Bank grant "Open data". There is no regular activity.

evidence.title: About the Open Data project

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.

There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse from various data topics.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by civil society organizations.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by media.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

indicators.justification:
First effort was made in 2014. But the government started to be more active only when it received the grant from the World Bank.

The Open Data Action Plan project (in short the Open Data Project) is an 18-month grant from the Trust Fund for Statistical Capacity Building (TFSCB). The amount of the grant is US $450,000 (Letter of Agreement between the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development / International Development Association (World Bank)) in 2018.

The project is being implemented with the support of the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) under the State Committee for Information Technologies and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic (GKITS KR).

Sources:
1) http://ict.gov.kg/index.php?r=site%2Fproject&pid=61&cid=24

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
There is a beneficial ownership definition and requirement to publish information only in the mining sector. This is outlined in the Law on subsoils of 19th of May, 2018. 

There is also a law on countering the financing of terrorist activities and legalization of money laundering of 6th of August 2018, where there is a requirement to ensure the transparency of beneficiaries of legal entities. Legal entities created and registered in the Kyrgyz Republic are obliged to form trustworthy and updated information about a physical person, which in the final result (through the chain of possession and control) directly or indirectly (through the third person) possesses the rights of a legal entity (legal entity); based on available and accessible information; to store information about the beneficial owner of the legal entity no less than five years from the date of its formation at the place of registration (discovery) of this legal entity.

Sources:
1) Position, dated December 25, 2018 No. 606, 
on the electronic database of beneficial owners of legal entities. http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/12930
2) Law of the Kyrgyz Republic, dated August 6, 2018 No. 87 on countering the financing of terrorist activities and legalization (laundering) of criminal proceeds. http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/111822
3) Law of the Kyrgyz Republic, dated May 19, 2018 No. 49 "About subsoils". http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/111782

indicators.justification:
There is no special legal framework or instructions regarding data management in Kyrgyzstan. There is only law № 213, as of December 28, 2006,  "About access to information contained in the management of state
bodies and bodies of local self-government of the Kyrgyz Republic", which discusses the obligation of the government to publish information it possesses. It doesn't discuss specific data management issues.

Sources: 
1) http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/202010

There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

indicators.justification:
The major framework on protection of personal data is the  Law of the Kyrgyz Republic "About the information of personal character", dated April 14, 2008, No. 58
http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/202269


The law on protection of personal data contradicts others about openness and transparency. Thus, the law on protection of personal data allows to collect data about financial status, health conditions only with the written permission of the citizens of Kyrgyzstan. However, the law on subsoils dated May 19, 2018 No. 49 requires the publication of information on beneficiaries openly, including personal data. 

Sources: 
1) http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/111782

indicators.justification:
There are two laws which require state bodies to publish information on public finance: the Law on access to information  held by state bodies and local self-government bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic dated July 27, 2016 No. 152, and the Budgetary Code dated May 16, 2016 No. 59. There is a specific outline of information which must be published by state bodies, along with a timeframe. There are also restrictions outlined in the Law of access to information (article 5).

Sources: 
1) Law of Kyrgyz Republic, dated December 28, 2006 No. 213 "On access to information held by state bodies and bodies of local self-government of the Kyrgyz Republic". http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/202010
2) Budgetary Code dated of May 16, 2016 No. 59. http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/111338
3) "Open budget" open data state owned web-portal https://budget.okmot.kg/ru

indicators.justification:
There is a relevant law providing a basis for collecting and publishing data on the interests and assets of public officials. But a person who wants to get the information may not find changes in the assets and liabilities. All assets have to be registered until a specific period of time. But we have to understand most government officials may have non-official assets which are registered by the people close to them.

indicators.justification: The data on land resources is not open. It can be obtained with a special written request and a fee. There is no special legal framework on land resources data, but the Law on access to information states that all state-owned data should be open when it doesn't contradict private data, commercial secrets, and national security. Despite this law, the data is not available.

There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
